Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2011 03:58AM lassman wrote: Hi, Have been on Xeloda for six months now and my SE's similar to nancyh. Bit of nausea which I control with anti-sickness meds and some tiredness. I always take the pills after food which helps with the nausea. So far feet and hands ok, although have had a few nail infections on big toe (not sure if related). I do still moisturise my feet just in case of problems though. I started taking B6 and this has made me feel better all over. I am on 14 days on 7 off regime. Taking 4000mg a day. Sometimes get excessive tearing with the eyes but this is intermittant and I put eye drops in when I get it. Not too bad really.  Lassman

Posts.Title: Feedback please -- just diagnosed with brain mets pq2 T-mac

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2010 01:47PM lassman wrote: Dear Schwartzina, I was in a similiar situation to you and your diagnosis almost the same as mine. I wanted a masto at first but surgeon talked me into doing neo-adjuvant therapy to try and shrink my tumour. Glad I did as I also had a complete response. Latte is right that once you have a mastectomy you can never go back. However, if you change your mind down the line you can always opt for the masto. Masto versus lumpectomy must be the hardest decision any woman can face. I did extensive research and all the info i came across said the mast v lump makes no difference to survival rates. There is, however, a slightly greater chance of a recurrance with a lumpectomy, although even this is small, especially if combined with rads. I decided I would take my chances and go with lumpectomy. Hope this helps you decide what to do. Best wishes Lassman
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy w/ Radiation or Mastectomy w/ Radiation schwartzina riley702

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2011 04:52AM lassman wrote: Loopey,  I also had a blue area that looked like a bruise (caused by the blue dye that they inject at the sentinel node biopsy stage). Mine lasted a year before finally dissapearing! The bottom half of my breast also went bright red and hot. This was no-where near the incision site from my lumpectomy. Eventually this also went away but some residually redness remains even now. They think it is mild breast lymphodoeama. Hope this helps.

Posts.Content: lassman wrote: Dear Ladies, Disaster has struck. Got rushed to hospital the other day. They thought i had had a stroke but a CT scan showed cause was mets to the brain (7 in all). I had a battery of tests to check for further spread in the body. Got the results back this morning and they confirm no (no) spread elsewhere. Bones/lungs/liver etc all clear. At least that is something. I start radiotherapy next week on brain. They will try and shrink the buggers. Hope it works. I will be moving to the stage 4 forum now and hope they can offer me some sage advice...I am well gutted... Best of luck to the rest of you - hope you don't end up in my situation. Lassman  Dx 4/5/2010, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 1/12 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

So then there was one...at 9mm lesion with no oedema - i thought all brain mets have some oedema? This has also shrunk. So it's on with the Xoleda and Tyverb and hope they stay away! Good news - i hope it lasts.  Body scan in a few weeks so expect serious scanxiety post. Next MRI might be interesting as well. This disease is so unfair and the uncertainty is the worst of it all. Thinking of you. Lassman

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2010 02:17PM lassman wrote: Angel180, Sometimes a hard lump under the scar is caused by a haematoma. My incision area went rock hard 8 days after surgery and it scared the hell out of me! Had a sono done and she confirmed it was a massive haematoma, she drained it whilst I was there. Was kinda weird watching it shrink on the screen! My nipple went east after surgery! Now after 3 months it's gone back to normal. Boob still itches and zaps though!. Lassman

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2011 06:33PM lassman wrote: Susansdot, The radiation continues to work for some time after WBR. I was told that things could get worse before they got better re symptoms. There is a lot of swelling after WBR and the more rads you have the worse symptoms can be. They would not scan me until eight weeks had passed before seeing if it had worked or not. Hang on in there! I agree with banjobanjo. Interogate your onc/radiologist as well! Hugs Lassman
Posts.Title: Brain mets and WBR Susansdot Bernicky

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2011 03:35PM lassman wrote: Hi Smilingdeb, I had a MUGA scan on Friday. It's basically an ultrasound of the heart to make sure it is functioning properly, since Herceptin can weaken it. They will check your "ejection fraction" which tells them how strong your heart muscle is. I have one every three months. As tests go it is a complete doddle (just have to rub lots of sticky goo off your chest afterwards!). I doubt they will check your lung with this scan. Hope this is helpful. Lassman
Posts.Title: Having my 1st MUGA Scan and have questions smilingdeb Outfield
